entry.title: 'We are supposed to be borderless': Why train travel in Europe is not up to speed
entry.summary: Is train travel in Europe up to scratch if people want a greener option to flying? Rail expert Jon Worth travelled 30,000km on 186 different trains across the continent to find out.

entry.title: The complete list of Iberia Express flights cancelled in Spain due to strikes
entry.summary: With the airline and unions failing to come to agreement in the latest round of talks, we outline all the cancelled flights during Iberia Express' strike action this week.

entry.title: AP PHOTOS: Kids reflect on war at bombed school in Ukraine
entry.summary: CHERNIHIV, Ukraine (AP) — Like children everywhere, returning to school in Ukraine comes with the excitement of reconnecting with friends mixed with an apprehension of teachers’ demands. The kids of school No. 21 now share a different common experience amid Russia’s war: Every student has become familiar with the sound of an air raid siren […]

entry.title: Skeleton found in 1985 identified as young girl who went missing 44 years ago in Indiana
entry.summary: The remains of Tracy Sue Walker, known for decades as ‘Baby Girl’, were found in northern Tennesee, more than 380 miles away from her home in Indiana

entry.title: What 24 hours of chaos in Iraq says about who controls the country
entry.summary: It took just 24 hours for Iraq's most powerful man to showcase his might on the streets of Baghdad on Monday, in what turned out to be one of the capital's most violent episodes in years.

entry.title: Austin, Inhofe mark anniversary of Afghan airport attack that killed 13 U.S. troops
entry.summary: Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin and Sen. Jim Inhofe of Oklahoma on Friday both marked the first anniversary of a terrorist attack outside Hamid Karzai International Airport that killed 13 U.S. military personnel.

entry.title: The Soviet Union once hunted endangered whales to the brink of extinction — but its scientists opposed whaling and secretly tracked its toll
entry.summary: The Soviet Union was a latecomer to industrial whaling, but it slaughtered whales by the thousands once it started and radically under-reported its toll to international monitors.

entry.title: Was this Canadian anchor fired for her gray hair?
entry.summary: After chief anchor Lisa LaFlamme was sacked, tons of speculation followed. Was it a budgetary decision? A personality clash with new management? Or maybe it had something to do with LaFlamme’s gray hair.

entry.title: Qatar treatment of migrant workers under spotlight again ahead of World Cup
entry.summary: The Gulf country of Qatar is facing criticism from human rights advocates after it arrested and deported a group of migrant workers who had protested months of overdue pay. This comes roughly three months before the nation is set to host the World Cup.

entry.title: Biden marks one-year anniversary of suicide attack that killed 13 U.S. troops amid Afghan withdrawal
entry.summary: President Biden marked the one-year anniversary of the suicide bombing at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, amid the chaotic U.S. withdrawal from the country by honoring the 13 U.S. service members killed in the attack.

entry.title: Lebanese submarine finds 10 bodies on sunken migrant ship
entry.summary: A Lebanese submarine has found the remains of at least 10 migrants who drowned when their boat sank earlier this year off the coast of Lebanon with about 30 people on board, the navy announced Friday.

entry.title: UN expert offers plan for improving human rights in Cambodia
entry.summary: The United Nations expert on human rights in Cambodia proposed on Friday a 10-point plan to improve rights in the Southeast Asian nation, describing it as a country with a bright future but some severe challenges.

entry.title: Latvia demolishes Soviet-era obelisk that towered over its capital for decades
entry.summary: Demolition crews in Latvia brought down a 260-foot monument erected during the Cold War that was seen as a symbol of the Soviet occupation of the Baltic country.

entry.title: Report: U.S. Coast Guard ship denied port call in Solomons
entry.summary: A U.S. coast guard cutter conducting patrols as part of an international mission to prevent illegal fishing was recently unable to get clearance for a scheduled port call in the Solomon Islands, according to reports, an incident that comes amid growing concerns of Chinese influence on the Pacific nation.

entry.title: The state of religion in France
entry.summary: For years, people have been questioning the concept of laicité — France's strict form of secularism — and how it plays into religious freedom. In this special hour of The World airing on Saturday, Paris-based reporter Rebecca Rosman takes a trip across France where she speaks to Catholics, Jews, Muslims and atheists about their right to believe, or not to believe.

entry.title: After Somalia hotel siege, a vow to tackle al-Shabab 'snake'
entry.summary: Hotels are refuges in Mogadishu, but targets, too. The al-Shabab extremist group, affiliated with al Qaeda, for years has carried out complex attacks on them, starting with explosions and holding out for hours as a handful of fighters exchanges gunfire with security forces until a bloody morning end.

entry.title: IAEA mission seeks to visit Zaporizhzhia plant in Ukraine amid concerns
entry.summary: A mission from the U.N.'s International Atomic Energy Agency is expected to visit the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant next week after it was temporarily knocked offline and more shelling was reported in the area overnight, Ukrainian officials said Friday.

entry.title: U.S. suspends Chinese airline flights in COVID-19 dispute
entry.summary: The U.S. government is suspending 26 flights by Chinese airlines from the United States to China in a dispute over anti-virus controls after Beijing suspended flights by American carriers.

entry.title: Russia divestment promises by U.S. states largely unfulfilled
entry.summary: Driven by moral outrage over Russia's invasion of Ukraine earlier this year, U.S. governors and other top state officials made it clear: They wanted to cut their financial ties with Russia.

entry.title: Britain to see 80% spike in energy bills as crisis deepens
entry.summary: Jennifer Jones keeps feeding money into her energy meter, but it never seems to be enough. And when she can't pay, she feels the impact immediately.

entry.title: Drought forces earliest harvest ever in French wine country
entry.summary: The landscape in the prestigious vineyards of Bordeaux looks the same as ever, with healthy, ripe grapes hanging heavy off rows of green vines.

entry.title: Nuclear treaty conference near end with Ukraine in spotlight
entry.summary: As 191 countries approach Friday's end to a four-week conference to review the landmark U.N. treaty aimed at curbing the spread of nuclear weapons, Russia's invasion of Ukraine and takeover of Europe's largest nuclear power plant and rivalries between the West and China were posing key obstacles to agreement on a final document.

entry.title: Abe murder suspect says life destroyed by mother's religion
entry.summary: The brazen assassination of former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe with a handmade gun shocked a nation unused to high-profile political violence.

entry.title: Ordinary Japanese 'salarymen' reach TikTok stardom
entry.summary: They're your run-of-the-mill "salarymen," as company workers in Japan are called -- hard-working, friendly and, well, rather regular.

entry.title: Medics on Ukraine’s front lines say war takes a heavy toll on mental health
entry.summary: Viktor Pylypenko and Yekaterina Pryimak have served as medics on the front lines in Ukraine against Russian aggression for the last six months. Both said that maintaining their mental health after six straight months of combat is difficult.

entry.title: Ukrainian nuclear plant temporarily cut off from power grid
entry.summary: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in the middle of the fighting in Ukraine was temporarily cut off from the electrical grid Thursday because of fire damage, causing a blackout in the region and heightening fears of a catastrophe in a country haunted by the Chernobyl disaster.

entry.title: Biden calls Volodymyr Zelenskyy to mark Ukraine's Independence Day
entry.summary: President Biden expressed his admiration for the people of Ukraine in a call Thursday with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

entry.title: Kenyan tennis star Angella Okutoyi inspires a new generation
entry.summary: Even since 18-year-old Angella Okutoyi's Wimbeldon win last month, she's been getting a lot of attention at home from aspiring tennis players. Her ascension in the sport comes after a long road of hard work, perseverance and determination against the odds.

entry.title: Syrian strikes, U.S. casualties complicate Biden's delicate diplomacy with Tehran
entry.summary: U.S. forces launched a series of deadly counterstrikes Thursday against Iran-backed militias inside Syria, the latest move in an escalating battle between the two sides that is casting a dark shadow over the Biden administration's push for a new nuclear deal with Tehran.

entry.title: US will support Ukraine against Russian aggression ‘as long as it takes,’ US State Dept. spokesperson says
entry.summary: Ned Price, the US State Department’s top spokesperson, told The World's host Carol Hills that the United States is prepared to support Ukraine for as long as necessary to defeat Russian aggression and to also defend themselves against any future aggression.

entry.title: Pope Francis won't see Russian Orthodox leader who plans to skip September summit
entry.summary: Pope Francis will not have an anticipated mid-September sitdown with Russian Orthodox leader Patriarch Kirill, the Moscow cleric's second-in-command said Wednesday.

entry.title: U.S. responds following Iran-backed rocket attack that injured three American troops
entry.summary: Militants backed by Iran fired rockets at two coalition bases in northeast Syria on Wednesday, injuring three U.S. military personnel and triggering an American response that resulted in the destruction of the vehicles and equipment used to launch them.
